dc:description:
KDM6A was first reported in relation to X-linked dominant Kabuki syndrome 2 (KS2) in 2012 (Lederer D et al., PMID: 22197486). Features of KS2 include neonatal feeding difficulties, hypoglycemia, postnatal growth retardation, motor delay, intellectual disability, microcephaly, congenital heart anomalies, palate defects, renal malformations, hearing loss, recurrent infections, joint hypermobility, and gastroesophageal reflux (Faundes V et al., PMID: 33674768). While Kabuki syndrome 1 (KS1) is characterized by distinct facial dysmorphism, facial phenotypes of patients with KS2 and KDM6A variants are highly variable. At least 13 unique variants (missense, nonsense, small insertion, splice site, small deletion) have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level and experimental data.

Summary of Case Level Data: 19.6
Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 13 probands in 6 publications (PMID: 22197486, PMID: 23076834, PMID: 24664873, PMID: 23913813, PMID: 30509212, PMID: 27302555). 

Summary of Experimental Data: 4.5
This gene-disease association is supported by multiple animal and cell culture models (PMID: 29073101, PMID: 25972376, PMID: 26431949, PMID: 34126175). Van Laarhoven PM et al., (2015) knocked down the expression of KDM6A orthologs in zebrafish (kdm6a and kdm6al). Morphants exhibited severe abnormalities in all tissues examined, presenting with craniofacial phenotypes and defects in heart development. Shpargel KB et al., (2017) demonstrated that mice carrying neural crest deletion of UTX (KDM6A) display craniofacial dysmorphism, cardiac defects, and postnatal growth retardation. Cook KD, et al., (2015) showed UTX-deficient T cells have decreased expression of interleukin-6 receptor-α and identified a critical link between UTX in T cells and immunity to infection.

In summary, there is definitive evidence to support the relationship between the KDM6A gene and X-linked dominant Kabuki syndrome 2, however, the variant spectrum and the phenotype of X-linked Kabuki syndrome type 2 are still not fully understood.

This classification was approved by the ClinGen SCID-CID GCEP on the meeting date July 15, 2021 (SOP Version 8).

evidence.dc:description: NM_021140.3(KDM6A):c.1555C>T (p.Arg519Ter), Authors identified a 1555C-T transition in the KDM6A gene, resulting in an arg519-to-ter (R519X) substitution.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2 Miyake
evidence.detectionMethod: Authors examined this gene’s 29 coding exons along with its exon-intron boundaries (NM_021140.2) in 32 KS individuals with no MLL2 mutation, using high-resolution melting analysis combined with direct sequencing. Authors identified c.1555C>T (p.Arg519∗) in patient 2 (hemizygous).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Lower palpebral eversion, Prominent ear, Auricular deformity, Abnormal dentition, severe intellectual disability, prenatal growth retardation, and postnatal growth retardation.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: No MLL2 mutations. Patient's growth delay and intellectual disability were much more severe than those of the other patients. At 22 years old, patient is unable to walk without support and speaks "no meaningful words."

evidence.dc:description: NM_021140.3(KDM6A):c.2515_2518del (p.Asn839fs), Authors identified a 4-bp deletion (c.2515_2518del) in exon 17 of the KDM6A gene, causing a frameshift predicted to result in a premature termination codon (Asn839ValfsTer27). The mother and maternal grandmother, who exhibited attenuated phenotypes, also carried the mutation, which was not found in an unaffected maternal aunt or in 144 controls.

evidence.rdfs:label: Lederer 2014 Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: The coding regions of KDM6A were then sequenced and a 4 bp deletion in exon 17 leading to a premature stop codon (c.2515_2518del, p.Asn839Valfs*27) was identified in the two affected brothers. This mutation was not found in 144 controls. Carrier testing in the proband’s mother, maternal grandmother, and the mother’s sister was performed. The mother and maternal grandmother were both carriers of this KDM6A mutation and the mother’s sister was not carrier. The mother did not have the typical KS phenotype but she had some KS features such as short stature, sparse lateral eyebrows, long palpebral fissures, neonatal teeth, brachydactyly, fetal finger pads, and hyperlaxity. The maternal grandmother’s facial features also did not have the typical gestalt of KS, but she shared some of these phenotypic characteristics including short stature, laterally sparse eyebrows, down-turned corners of the mouth, and brachydactyly with the mother. All those features have been reported in KS. These phenotypic characteristics were not found in the mother’s sister. Molecular X-inactivation studies (PCR amplification of the CAG repeat in exon 1 of the androgen receptor gene before and after DNA digestion with HpaIIand CfoI) in the mother and grandmother failed to provide skewing data because of homozygous status (data not shown).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Severe right ventricular outflow obstruction with a critical pulmonary stenosis, hypoplastic right ventricle, and atrio-ventricular septal defect. Short stature. Birth weight was 2.45 kg (2nd–9th centile). Gastro-esophageal reflux. Recurrent episodes of otitis media requiring grom-met insertion. He had myopia, strabismus and nystagmus.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Nonconsanguineousparents. MLL2 sequencing including intron-exon boundaries in the proband detected four polymorphisms, none of which were pathogenic.

evidence.dc:description: NM_021140.3(KDM6A):c.3717G>A (p.Trp1239Ter), Authors identified a 3717G-A transition in the KDM6A gene, resulting in a trp1239-to-ter (W1239X) substitution.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1 Miyake
evidence.detectionMethod: Authors examined this gene’s 29 coding exons along with its exon-intron boundaries (NM_021140.2) in 32 KS individuals with no MLL2 mutation, using high-resolution melting analysis combined with direct sequencing. Authors identified c.3717G>A (p.Trp1239∗) in patient 1 (hemizygous).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Lower palpebral eversion, Prominent ear, Auricular deformity, Abnormal dentition, Prenatal growth retardation, Postnatal growth retardation, Cardiovascular abnormality, Deafness due to otitis media, severe intellectual disability, and recurrent pneumonia. At age 14 years, patient finds it difficult to walk without support.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: No MLL2 mutation. Born to unrelated healthy parents and has a healthy brother.

evidence.dc:description: NM_001291415.2:c.335-1G>T, male patient with a novel KDM6A splicing in exon(exon4) and flanking intron(intron3)-exon boundaries characterized by congenital hydrocephalus which had never been reported before. The patient inherited the c.335-1G > T splice site mutation from the mother who had fewer dysmorphic features than the patient who displayed a more severe phenotype with multiple organ involvement.

evidence.rdfs:label: Guo 2018 Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA was isolated from peripheral-blood leukocytes, whole-genome CNV was obtained by NGS. Whole-genome analyses of CNV have not found definite pathogenic gene. All 19 coding exons of KDM6A and flanking intron-exon boundaries sequenced by medical exome sequencing and samples were sequenced. KDM6A gene was discovered c.335-1G > T splice site mutation in exon(exon4) and flanking intron(intron3)-exon boundaries. Sanger sequencing was performed in the patient to validate KDM6A gene mutation status, and the patient had inherited the c.335-1G > T splice-site mutation from the mother.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Inability to lift the head and weak crying. Couldn’t accomplish the tests of audio and visual tracking. Eversion of the lateral part of the lower eyelid, large prominent ears with low set ears, gingival thickening. CT scan revealed hydrocephalus, ultrasonography showed developmental dysplasia of hip. Hypotonia, no pathological reflex.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Liver and kidney functions, thyroid function, blood counts, electrolytes were normal. G-banding karyotyping showed that the patient had macroscopically normal chromosomes. Heritage metabolic disease screening and antibody testing of maternal intrauterine infection were negative.

evidence.dc:description: NM_001291415.2(KDM6A):c.3507TCT[1] (p.Leu1171del), Authors identified a de novo heterozygous 3-bp deletion (c.3354_3356delTCT) in the KDM6A gene, resulting in the in-frame deletion of a highly conserved residue (leu1119del) in the catalytic Jumonji-C (JmjC) domain. The mutation was not present in either of the parents. The patient showed a random pattern of X inactivation, with a 57:43 ratio in genomic DNA from peripheral leukocytes.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 3 Miyake
evidence.detectionMethod: Authors examined this gene’s 29 coding exons along with its exon-intron boundaries (NM_021140.2) in 32 KS individuals with no MLL2 mutation, using high-resolution melting analysis combined with direct sequencing. Authors identified c.3354_3356delTCT (p.Leu1119del) in patient 3 (heterozygous).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Long palpebral fissures, lower palpebral eversion, postnatal growth retardation.

evidence.dc:description: NM_021140.3(KDM6A):c.1909_1912del (p.Ser637fs), Individual KMS-81 with a frame-shift mutation showed marked skewing. By RT-PCR using mRNA derived from a lymphoblastoid cell line from patient KMS-81, authors confirmed that both the mutated and normal alleles were transcribed at similar levels when nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (NMD) was inhibited by cycloheximide treatment. In untreated cells, or cells treated with dimethyl-sulfoxide (negative control), the mutant allele was transcribed at a lower level than the wild-type allele, indicating that NMD partially eliminated the mutant.

evidence.rdfs:label: KMS-81
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted resequencing. Patient KMS-81, who had a truncating-type mutation, showed marked skewing. X-inactivation skewing was also reported in two affected females with KDM6A deletion reported by Lederer et al. (2012). cDNA sequence analysis of patient KMS-81 indicated that the mutant allele of KDM6A was expressed at a similar level to the wild-type allele under NMD inhibition. This result suggests that KDM6A mostly escapes X-inactivation in female lymphoblastoid cells. Interestingly, KDM6A/Kdm6a escapes X-inactivation in humans and mice, and in mice its expression level from the inactive X chromosome(Xi) was reported as 15–35% of that from the active X chromosome(Xa) (Greenfield et al., 1998; Xu et al., 2008).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Large front teeth with wide interdentium. Short stature and postnatal growth retardation.

evidence.dc:description: NM_001291415.2(KDM6A):c.514C>T (p.Arg172Ter), Nonsense variant and de novo.

evidence.rdfs:label: P210
evidence.detectionMethod: Sanger sequencing of KDM6A. For de novo analysis, all variant loci in the patient’s dataset were compared with the parental datasets.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Horseshoe kidney, Small for gestational age, Short stature, Microcephaly, Long palpebral fissures, Arched eyebrows, Lateral sparseness of eyebrows, High arched palate, Selective tooth agenesis, Malocclusion, Prominent upper incisors, Brachydactyly of the fifth finger, Clinodactyly of the fifth finger, Persistent fetal finger pads, Intellectual disability, Feeding difficulties, and Neonatal hypoglycemia.

evidence.dc:description: NM_001291415.2(KDM6A):c.190G>T (p.Glu64Ter), nonsense variant and de novo.

evidence.rdfs:label: P209
evidence.detectionMethod: Sanger sequencing of KDM6A. For de novo analysis, all variant loci in the patient’s dataset were compared with the parental datasets.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Ureteral duplication and hydronephrosis, Large/dysplastic ears, Long palpebral fissures, Arched eyebrows, Lateral sparseness of eyebrows, Depressed nasal tip, Short columella, Downslanting corners of mouth, High arched palate, Micrognathia, Brachydactyly of the fifth finger, Clinodactyly of the fifth finger, Joint laxity, Thin temporal hair (infancy), Intellectual disability, Muscular hypotonia, Feeding difficulties, ASD/VSD (heart defects), Sacral dimple and Simian crease.

evidence.dc:description: NM_001291415.2(KDM6A):c.171dup (p.Gly58TrpfsTer7),  N-terminal truncating mutation and de novo.

evidence.rdfs:label: P212
evidence.detectionMethod: Trio WES in a KMT2D mutation-negative patient (P212) identified the novel one-base pair duplication c.171dupT in exon 2 of KDM6A. This mutation leads to a frameshift and a premature stop codon at amino acid position 64: p.(Gly58Trpfs∗7). De novo occurrence was observed in the WES data sets and subsequently confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Microcephaly, Large/dysplastic ears, Long palpebral fissures, Eversion of the lower eyelid, Long, thick eyelashes, Arched eyebrows, Lateral sparseness of eyebrows, Depressed nasal tip, Short columella, Downslanting corners of mouth, Micrognathia, Brachydactyly of the fifth finger, Hip dysplasia, Joint laxity, Thin temporal hair (infancy), Persistent fetal finger pads, Intellectual disability, Muscular hypotonia, Feeding difficulties, Seizures, corticalatrophy and white matter anomalies, Pulmonary infections, Frequent upper airway infections, and Recurrent otitis media in infancy.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: P212 was the only patient who had already been included in a previous mutation screening study (Li et al., 2011).  Negative for a mutation in KMT2D.

evidence.dc:description: NM_001291415.2(KDM6A):c.619+6T>C, splice site variant and de novo.

evidence.rdfs:label: P218
evidence.detectionMethod: Sanger sequencing of KDM6A. For de novo analysis, all variant loci in the patient’s dataset were compared with the parental datasets.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Large/dysplastic ears, Long palpebral fissures, Eversion of the lower eyelid, Blue sclerae, Arched eyebrows, Lateral sparseness of eyebrows, Short columella, Downslanting corners of mouth, Nail dystrophy, Persistent fetal finger pads, Intellectual disability, Muscular hypotonia, Feeding difficulties, ASD/VSD (heart defects), Isolated persistent left superior vena cava, and hyperinsulinism.

evidence.dc:description: nsv1067838, Authors identified hemizygosity for a de novo 45.4-kb intragenic deletion from genomic coordinate chrX:44,866,302 to 44,912,718 (GRCh37/hg19), removing exons 5 through 9 of the KDM6A gene. Not stated if the mother has been tested, no additional points for de novo.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 3 Lederer
evidence.detectionMethod: Authors sequenced KDM6A by Sanger sequencing and looked for intragenic deletions or duplications with a targeted custom Agilent array CGH in a cohort of 22 MLL2-mutation negative KS individuals.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Typical KS phenotype, areolar fullness in infancy, persistent finger pads, feeding difficulties in infancy, IQ Tot: 54 (examined at 14 months of age with the Griffith Mental Developmental Scale), arched eyebrow, lateral sparse of the eyebrow, long palpebral fissure, long eyelashes, eversion of lateral third of the inferior eyelid, short columella, dental malocclusion, prominent and cupped ears.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Authors also sequenced UTY, the Y chromosome paralog of KDM6A, and looked for intragenic deletions or duplications as stated above, but did not detect any mutations.

evidence.dc:description: NM_001291415.2(KDM6A):c.2885A>G (p.Asn962Ser), missense mutation considered to be most likely disease-causing with reduced penetrance. Patient P214 inherited the KDM6A mutation from his seemingly unaffected mother. Authors suggest reduced expressivity or even reduced penetrance of the KS2 phenotype in females.

evidence.rdfs:label: P214
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Microcephaly, Large/dysplastic ears, Long palpebral fissures, Long, thick eyelashes, Arched eyebrows, Depressed nasal tip, Short columella, Cleft palate, Malocclusion, Brachydactyly of the fifth finger, Clinodactyly of the fifth finger, Joint laxity, Persistent fetal finger pads, Intellectual disability, and Thorax asymmetry.

evidence.dc:description: NM_021140.3(KDM6A):c.3763C>T (p.Arg1255Trp), missense variant and de novo.

evidence.rdfs:label: P216
evidence.detectionMethod: Sanger sequencing of KDM6A. For de novo analysis, all variant loci in the patient’s dataset were compared with the parental datasets.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Large/dysplastic ears, Long palpebral fissures, Eversion of the lower eyelid, Long, thick eyelashes, Blue sclerae, Arched eyebrows, Lateral sparseness of eyebrows, Depressed nasal tip, Short columella, Downslanting corners of mouth, High arched palate, Brachydactyly of the fifth finger, Joint laxity, Thin temporal hair (infancy), Persistent fetal finger pads, Muscular hypotonia, Coarctation of Aorta, Frequent upper airway infections, Premature thelarche, Bicuspid aortic valve, and accessory spleen.

evidence.dc:description: Results provide further support for the similar roles of KMT2D and KDM6A in the etiology of KS by using a vertebrate model organism to provide direct evidence of their roles in the development of organs and tissues affected in KS patients.
The kdm6a and kdm6al morphants had similar brain abnormalities, kdm6a morphants exhibited craniofacial phenotypes, whereas kdm6al morphants had prominent defects in heart development.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish KDM6A Knock Down

evidence.dc:description: Authors identify a critical link between UTX in T cells and immunity to infection.

UTX-deficient T cells showed decreased expression of interleukin-6 receptor-α and other Tfh cell-related genes that were associated with increased H3K27 methylation. Additionally, Turner Syndrome subjects, who are predisposed to chronic ear infections, had reduced UTX expression in immune cells and decreased circulating CD4+ CXCR5+ T cell frequency.
evidence.rdfs:label: UTX and T follicular helper (Tfh) cell responses

evidence.dc:description: NC-specific knockout of Utx (KDM6A) establishes a mouse model for Kabuki syndrome that exhibits many features of the human disorder. MKO (male) mice have a Kabuki-like manifestation of mild craniofacial features and postnatal growth retardation, indicative of demethylase-dependent UTX function. FKO (female) mice have more severe growth, craniofacial, and cardiac abnormalities. Thus, UTY performs some demethylase-independent UTX compensation in NC development. UTY only partially compensates for loss of UTX in mouse NC, creating an allelic phenotypic gradient. Heterozygous Utx females having one copy of Utx are asymptomatic for facial phenotypes, MKO having one copy of Uty manifest mild phenotypes, and FKO completely lacking both homologs are more severely affected. Similar dosage sensitivity exists in Kabuki patients. UTX−/y males have more severe developmental delay and learning disabilities compared with UTX+/− females (11, 16, 23). Therefore, UTY has some function, but a single copy of UTY (UTX−/y) is not as functional as a single copy of UTX (UTX+/−).

MKO mice exhibited frontonasal hypoplasia with a depressed snout, an increased facial angle producing a more prominent forehead, and reduced palpebral fissures (Fig. 1C). FKO mice displayed enhanced MKO characteristics, including greater facial depression, a broader dome-shaped forehead, severe palpebral fissure reduction, and rounded low-set earlobes (Fig. 1C). Partially penetrant cleft palate was specific to FKO embryos (Fig. 1D). Furthermore, FKO mice also exhibited patent ductus arteriosus congenital heart defects (Fig. 1E) without abnormalities in ventricular septal closure (Fig. S1A).
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse Model Neural Crest Deletion of UTX (KDM6A)

evidence.dc:description: Data indicate a critical role for KDM6A in the regulation of hematopoietic differentiation and differentiation-specific gene expression programs, with a prominent role in early B-cell differentiation that is likely independent of H3K27 methylation status.

Lack of Kdm6a affects female but not male hematopoiesis. Lack of KDM6A does not alter global levels of H3K27 methylation, its presumed target, and might thus function independently of histone demethylation. KDM6A is essential for the regulation of stress hematopoiesis. Absence of KDM6A affects primarily B-cell differentiation, which is initiated at the level of HSPCs.
evidence.rdfs:label: KDM6A Stress Hematopoiesis and B Cell Differentiation
